request_pathways.name: Authorization to Release or Obtain Health Information (English)
Autorización para Divulgar u Obtener Información Médica (Spanish)
Mail to Medical Records Department (575 Main Street, Middletown, CT 06457)

forms.document_type: ROI authorization form (Birth to Three program variant)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients use a generic HIPAA authorization form that serves dual purposes (release to third party and obtain from third party), with an embedded self-request delivery section; the website now directs to Luma Health online portals.

red_flags: Default 3-year scope limitation may restrict patients who don't explicitly request their full record
Reason for request field included, which is not required for patient self-access under HIPAA
bright_spots: Spanish-language version of the ROI form available
Email delivery option offered for patient self-requests
Granular exclusion controls for drug/alcohol information
Single-page form design keeps process concise
Transition to Luma Health online portal for modernized workflow

findability.rationale: Level 3: Requires moderate effort — the patient forms page exists and is navigable, but the PDF forms are legacy documents no longer linked from it; the current page directs to Luma Health portals, while PDFs are only discoverable via web search.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Usable digitally with workarounds; fax submission available — the PDF has a text layer but zero fillable fields, requiring print-and-handwrite completion, with fax as the electronic submission method.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized single-page form with clear section headers and logical flow; minor issues include dense legal text at the bottom and unexplained telephone encounter distinction in record type options.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the generic authorization form accommodates self-requests via a delivery sub-section, but does not distinguish patient access rights from third-party release authorization.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities — no notarization or in-person requirements, 30-day timeline stated, revocation rights disclosed; however, the reason-for-request field and default 3-year scope limitation go slightly beyond what HIPAA requires for patient access.

overall.summary: CHC provides a functional but undifferentiated patient access pathway through a generic authorization form with a self-request section, multilingual support, and email delivery — but non-fillable fields, lack of dedicated patient access form, and minor compliance gaps limit the overall experience.
